isis.stitle: TSI 93-12-02 - The Use of Propylene Glycol Antifreeze

subjectgroup.subject: The Use of Propylene Glycol Antifreeze

geninfo.para: This TSI describes the use of Propylene Glycol Antifreeze in all vehicle engines (except Detroit Diesel).

There has been some interest in and questions asked about the use of propylene glycol antifreeze (PG) in Navistar vehicles, especially the mixing of PG with ethylene glycol (EG), the antifreeze put in the cooling system of Navistar vehicles during production. There is no detrimental effect on the cooling system or system performance if PG is put in the cooling system or if EG and PG are mixed. However, the following information shows why it is not recommended that PG antifreeze be mixed with EG antifreeze.

item.para: The freeze protection measuring devices will not give the right answers if the two types of antifreeze are mixed. The bubble tube measuring device is not suitable. If a dual scale refractometer is used, the average of the PG and EG readings will give a measurement of the protection level of the antifreeze mixture that may be as much as 7 degrees off.
The freeze protection of PG is slightly inferior to EG, but should not be a problem except in borderline conditions.
Adding EG to PG will increase toxicity. However, USED ANTIFREEZE OF ANY TYPE SHOULD BE DISPOSED OF IN ACCORDANCE WITH APPLICABLE FEDERAL AND LOCAL REGULATIONS.

Corrosion protection additives are similar for both EG and PG antifreezes; therefore, test kits suitable for EG will work with PG. The test kit should be matched to the type of supplemental coolant additive used: Fleetrite kit with Fleetrite filters and Liquid SCA, etc.

geninfo.para: During the first two years after the vehicle is manufactured, the coolant system will most likely be filled with EG and it is recommended that EG be added to the system when required, as a mixture of EG and PG will create the above conditions.
